revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Kent Design Awards | description = To celebrate the high quality development delivered throughout Kent | presenter = Kent Design Initiative (part of [[Kent County Council]]) | country = [[UK]] | year = 2003 | holder = | website = [http://www.kent.gov.uk/community_and_living/regeneration_and_economy/kent_design_initiative/design_awards/about_the_awards.aspx Kent Design Initiative] }} These awards were created to celebrate design excellence in Kent and were first staged in 2003 and are usually held every two years.<ref name=design2010>{{cite web |first=Hannah | last=Ratcliffe |url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/kent/hi/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_8571000/8571992.stm |title =Unique design and architecture in Kent is awarded |website =bbc.co.uk |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref> They were then renamed 'Kent Design and Development Awards' in 2012. Then have stayed as the 'Kent Design and Development Awards' in 2014.<ref name=design2010/>
==2003==
* Commercial and Industrial Building winner - [[HolidayExtras.com|Holiday Extras HQ Building]], [[Newingreen]], [[Hythe, Kent|Hythe]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.holidayextras.co.uk/about-us/awards-archive.html?agent=WM076&awc=3496_1387894886_f9a236a0f1c6f79d68a80785c5790a99 |title =Holiday Extras® Awards Archive |website =www.holidayextras.co.uk |year=2003 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref> * Public Building winner - Riverhead Infant School, Sevenoaks * Urban Design and Town Centre Renewal winner - St. Mildreds Lavender Mews, [[Canterbury]] * Best Individual House - Lynwood, Tunbridge Wells (private residence)<ref name=lynwood>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbsconstruction.com/cs-new-house-lynwood.php |title =Case Studies |website =www.bbsconstruction.com |year=2002 |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> * Housebuilding for Quality winner - Ingress Park, [[Greenhithe]] * Overall winner - Lynwood, Tunbridge Wells (private residence)<ref name=lynwood/>
Highly Commended was [[Romney Warren Country Park|Romney Warren Visitor Centre]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecolibriumsolutions.co.uk/projects/romney-warren-visitor-centre/ |title =Romney Marsh Visitor Centre |website =www.ecolibriumsolutions.co.uk |year=2003 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref>
==2004== * Housebuilding for Quality winner - Vista (private residence), [[Dungeness (headland)|Dungeness]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arts.theguardian.com/pictures/image/0,8543,-10604950018,00.html |title =Riba award winners 2004 |website =arts.theguardian.com |year=2004| accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref> * Public Building/Education winner - St Augustine's RC School, [[Hythe, Kent|Hythe]]<ref name=RCschool>{{cite web |url=http://architecturecentre.org/documents/education/learning_by_design_staugustines.pdf |title =Information about St. Augustine’s Primary School |website =architecturecentre.org |date=25 April 2007| accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref> * Town and Village Renaissance - Horsebridge and Brownings Yard, [[Whitstable]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clague.co.uk/sector-details.asp?CategoryID=10 |title=Portfolio |website=www.clague.co.uk |year=2004 |accessdate=16 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118061023/http://www.clague.co.uk/sector-details.asp?CategoryID=10 |archivedate=18 January 2014 |df= }}</ref> * Overall Winner - St Augustine's RC School, Hythe <ref name=RCschool/>
==2005/2006== * Public Building winner - [[Trosley Country Park]] amenity block <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecolibriumsolutions.co.uk/projects/country-park-amenity-block/ |title =Country park amenity block Trosley Country Park, Kent |website =www.ecolibriumsolutions.co.uk |year=2005 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref> * Commercial, Industrial and retail winner - [[Kings Hill]] Village Centre <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lee-evans.co.uk/portfolio-item/kings-hill-village-centre/ |title =Kings Hill Village Centre |website =www.lee-evans.co.uk |year=2005 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref> * Housebuilding winner - Iden Farm Cottage, [[Boughton Monchelsea]], near [[Maidstone]]<ref name=convertedrailshed>{{cite web |date=2 December 2005 |title=Top design award for converted rail shed |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentonline/newsarchive.aspx?articleid=23955 |website =www.kentonline.co.uk |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> * Building Renovation winner - The Old Gymnasium, Deal Cavalry Barracks, [[Deal, Kent|Deal]]<ref name=convertedrailshed/> * Best New Neighbourhood winner - Affordable village housing in Ash Grove, [[St Margaret's at Cliffe]], near Dover.<ref name=convertedrailshed/> * Overall Winner - The Goods Shed, Canterbury <ref name=convertedrailshed/>
==2007/2008== Also nominated was [[Sevenoaks]] Kaleidoscope museum, library and gallery, although misleadingly named as a winner on an architects brochure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clayarchitecture.com/_literature_109963/Clay_Brochure_March_2013_-_format_pdf |title =Clay Architecture |website =www.clayarchitecture.com |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=30 December 2013 }}</ref>
* Commercial, Industrial and retail winner - Broadside (HQ of MHS Homes), Chatham <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ancon.co.uk/projects/broadside-chatham-maritime-kent-uk |title=Broadside, Chatham Maritime, Kent, UK |website=www.ancon.co.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=16 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221130216/http://www.ancon.co.uk/projects/broadside-chatham-maritime-kent-uk |archivedate=21 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> * Housebuilding winner - Sandling Park (a residential scheme), Maidstone<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.housingexcellence.co.uk/news/sandling-park-wins-kent-design-award-138350 |title =Sandling Park wins Kent Design Award |website =www.housingexcellence.co.uk |date=13 December 2007 |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> * Building Renovation (joint winners) - Pilkington Building <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rmjm.com/portfolio/pilkington-building-universities-at-medway-england/ |title =Pilkington Building, Universities at Medway, England |website =www.rmjm.com |year=2007 |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> and [[Drill Hall Library]], within the [[Universities at Medway]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://enterprise.gre.ac.uk/news/articles/2007news/a1477-kent-sesign-awards |title =Medway Campus collects First Prize at Kent Design Awards |website =enterprise.gre.ac.uk |date=6 December 2007 |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> * Public Building winner - Parrock Street public toilets, [[Gravesend, Kent|Gravesend]] (Gravesham Community Project PFI)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.plastikarchitects.com/parrock-street/ |title =Parrock Street |website =www.plastikarchitects.com |year=2007 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref> * Landscape category winner - [[Lower Leas Coastal Park]], [[Folkestone]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentnordpasdecalais.com/activities/amphitheatre/?lang=en|title=Amphitheatre|website=www.kentnordpasdecalais.com|year=2012|accessdate=5 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140107054530/http://www.kentnordpasdecalais.com/activities/amphitheatre/?lang=en|archivedate=7 January 2014|df=}}</ref> * Overall Winner - [[Pines Garden#The Calyx Centre|The Pines Calyx]], St Margaret's at Cliffe
==2010== 30 projects were shortlisted in seven categories from more than 60 entries. The Medway Building at the [[University of Kent]] as part of the [[Universities at Medway]], was nominated for Best Public Building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.e-architect.co.uk/england/medway-building |title =Medway Building, Kent, England |website =www.e-architect.co.uk |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref> Also nominated was Crossway Low Energy House, near [[Maidstone]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jhai.co.uk/project/case-study-crossway-low-energy-house-kent |title =Case Study Crossway Low Energy House, Kent |website =www.jhai.co.uk |year=2009|accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref>
* Conservation & Craftsmanship Category winner - The [[Darnley Mausoleum]], [[Cobham, Kent|Cobham]] <ref name=design2010/> * Town & Village Renaissance winner - [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]] [[Shared Space]] * Residential overall winner - The Quays (towers with the former [[Chatham Dockyard]]), [[Chatham Maritime]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ardmoregroup.co.uk/news/awards/ |title=Awards |website=www.ardmoregroup.co.uk |year=2010 |accessdate=24 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305073127/http://www.ardmoregroup.co.uk/news/awards/ |archivedate= 5 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> * Residential (major development) winner - The Quays, [[Chatham Maritime]] * Residential (minor development) winner - El Ray, Dungeness * Commercial, Industrial & Retail winner - [[Deal Pier]] * Public Buildings (general) winner - Quarterhouse, [[Folkestone]] <ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.alisonbrooksarchitects.com/studio/awards/ |title =Awards | website=www.alisonbrooksarchitects.com |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref> * Public Buildings (schools) winner - St. James the Great Primary & Nursery School, [[East Malling]] * Project of the Year - the [[Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, Baron Bruce-Lockhart|Lord Sandy Bruce-Lockhart]] Award - The Darnley Mausoleum, Cobham <ref name=design2010/>
==2012 (Renamed as 'Kent Design and Development Awards')== Jointly organised and sponsored by 'DHA Planning'(town planning and transport consultancy), Kent County Council and Ward Homes (public housing management).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://architecture-centre.org/2012/05/30/kent-design-and-development-awards-2012/ |title =KENT DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT AWARDS 2012 |website =architecture-centre.org |year=2012 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}</ref>
94 nominees including [[Sevenoaks School]] Performing Arts Centre and [[Cornwallis Academy]].<ref name=design2012>{{cite web |first=Kasan | last=Goh |url =http://www.clayarchitecture.com/blog/kent_design_award_2012_for_best_public_building_-_education_ |title =Kent Design Award 2012 for Best Public Building ( Education ) |website =www.clayarchitecture.com |date=6 December 2012 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref>
* Commercial, Industrial and Retail winner - Rocksalt Restaurant, Folkestone * Public Buildings Education winner - [[Marlowe Theatre]],Canterbury <ref name=design2012/> * Civils and Infrastructure winner - [[Dover]] Esplande, sea frontage * Environmental Performance winner - [[Hadlow College]] * Minor Residential winner - Hill House, [[Ulcombe]] <ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.workingmetals.co.uk/hill-house.php |title =Hill House, Kent - 2012 RIBA Award Winner |website =www.workingmetals.co.uk |year=2012 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref> * Major Residential winner - Rosemary Gardens, [[Park Wood, Maidstone|Park Wood]] <ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.goldinghomes.org.uk/completed-developments/rosemary-gardens-park-wood-613/ |title =Rosemary Gardens, Park Wood |website =www.goldinghomes.org.uk |year=2012 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref> * Public Buildings, Community winner - [[Turner Contemporary]] * Public Buildings, Education winner - [[Walderslade]] Primary School <ref name=design2012/> * Project of the Year (Sponsored by DHA Planning) - Rocksalt Restaurant, Folkestone <ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.mlm.uk.com/news_article.php?newsid=37 |title =Rocksalt Restaurant Winner at Kent Design Awards |website =www.mlm.uk.com |year=2012 |accessdate=23 December 2013 }}</ref>
==2014 Kent Design and Development Awards== The shortlist was announced in September 2014;<ref>{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Britcher|title=Architects hope grand designs build on community benefits| newspaper=Kent on Sunday|location=Kent| date=28 September 2014}}</ref> Categories Include: * Major Residential category - Horsted Park, Chatham * Minor Residential category - Pobble House, Romney Marsh * Commercial, Industrial and Retail category - Medway Crematorium * Civils and Infrastructure category - [[Sandwich, Kent|Sandwich Town]] Tidal Defences * Education Public Buildings category - Goat Lees Primary School, Ashford * Community Public Buildings category - [[Cyclopark]], Gravesend * Environmental Performance category - Goat Lees Primary School, Ashford
Overall winner ‘Project of the year’ - Goat Lees Primary School, Ashford,<ref>{{cite web|title=2014 winners|url=http://www.kentdesigndevelopmentawards.co.uk/p/2014-winners.html|accessdate=12 November 2017}}</ref>
==2016 Awards== Twenty-three developments were shortlisted for the eight categories; Winners: * Commercial, Industrial and Retail category - The Wing, Capel-le-Ferne * Conservation category - Command of the Oceans at [[Chatham Historic Dockyard]], * Environmental Performance category - North Vat, a house near [[Dungeness (headland)|Dungeness]], * Infrastructure and Renewables category - the cut and cover tunnel at Hermitage Quarry, Barming, by [[Gallagher Group (UK)|Gallagher Ltd]], * Education Public Buildings category - The Yarrow in [[Broadstairs]], * Community Public Buildings category - Fairfield (part of [[East Kent College]]) in [[Dartford]] * Minor Residential category - Nautical Mews in Margate, * Major Residential category - Farrow Court in [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]] and Wallis Fields in [[Maidstone]],
[[Battle of Britain Memorial, Capel-le-Ferne|The Wing]] for the Battle of Britain Memorial Trust at [[Capel-le-Ferne]] was named Project of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Announcing the winners of the Kent Design and Development awards|url=http://www.kentdesigndevelopmentawards.co.uk/2016/12/announcing-winners-of-kent-design-and.html#more|year=2016|publisher=kentdesigndevelopmentawards.co.uk|accessdate=12 November 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QofLxxroK5Y Kent Design and Development Awards 2012 ]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Dresden]]; added [[Category:Staatliche Kunstsammlungen Dresden]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:Dürer-Hieronymus-im-Gehäus.jpg|thumb|''[[Saint Jerome in His Study (Dürer)|St. Jerome in His Study]]'', engraving by [[Albrecht Dürer]], 1514.]] The '''Kupferstich-Kabinett''' (English: '''Collection of Prints, Drawings and Photographs''') is part of the [[Staatliche Kunstsammlungen Dresden|Staatliche Kunstsammlungen]] (State Art Collections) of [[Dresden]], [[Germany]]. Since 2004 it has been located in [[Dresden Castle]].<ref name=dus>[http://www.dresden-und-sachsen.de/dresden/ks_kupferstichkabinett.htm Kupferstich-Kabinett] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720084737/http://www.dresden-und-sachsen.de/dresden/ks_kupferstichkabinett.htm |date=2011-07-20 }} Information and history from the Dresden and Saxony tourist website. {{de icon}}</ref>
==History==
Like many of Dresden's notable collections, this [[print room]] traces its origins to the [[Electorate of Saxony|Prince-electors of Saxony]]. The art chamber of the [[House of Wettin]], established around 1560, became an independent museum of prints and drawings in 1720.<ref name=dus /><ref name=melzer>[http://www.riha-journal.org/articles/2010/melzer-vorgeschichte-dresdner-kupferstich-kabinett Zur Vorgeschichte des Dresdner Kupferstich-Kabinetts zwischen 1560 und 1738] Christian Melzer, ''Journal of the International Association of Research Institutes in the History of Art'', '''0004'''. 21 June 2010. Retrieved 8 September 2010. {{de icon}}</ref> The collection was expanded in the following centuries. It now describes itself as the oldest museum of graphic arts in the German-speaking world.
Because most items had been evacuated to [[Schloss Weesenstein]] in the early stages of [[World War II]], the collection was saved from the [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II|bombing of Dresden]] in February 1945.<ref name=skd>{{cite web |url= http://www.skd.museum/en/museums-institutions/residenzschloss/kupferstich-kabinett/history-of-the-collection/|title= History of the Collection|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher= Staatliche Kunstsammlung Dresden|access-date= 6 September 2015|quote=}}</ref> War-time losses were still high; around 50,000 items are still missing.<ref name=skd/> Most of the exhibits were [[Looted_art#Looting_by_the_Soviet_Union|looted]] by the [[Soviet Union]] after the war and did not return to Dresden until the late 1950s,<ref name=dus /> and some when they were put back on display in the [[Albertinum]].
==Collection== [[File:Jan van Eyck - Portrait of Cardinal Niccolò Albergati - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''[[Study for Cardinal Niccolò Albergati]]'', attributed to [[Jan van Eyck]], c. 1431]] The collection includes over 500,000 items, only a fraction of which can be exhibited. The most renowned artists in the collection include [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], [[Albrecht Dürer]], [[Jan van Eyck]], [[Francisco de Goya]], [[Hans Holbein the Younger]], [[Michelangelo]], [[Rembrandt]], and [[Rubens]]. There is also a large number of works by artists with strong connections to Dresden, such as [[Caspar David Friedrich]], [[Ludwig Richter]], [[Georg Baselitz]] and [[Johannes Heisig]]. The collection of [[Käthe Kollwitz]] was started in 1898 and now numbers over 200 works from her oeuvre of drawings and graphics.<ref name=dus />
Besides the permanent exhibition, the Kupferstichkabinett also hosts regular special exhibitions featuring both its own works and those on loan from other notable museums.
==See also== [[List of museums in Saxony]]
==Notes and references== <references/> ==External links== * [https://kupferstich-kabinett.skd.museum/en/ Kupferstichkabinett Homepage] of the [[Dresden State Art Collections]]
{{Commons category|Kupferstich-Kabinett (Dresden)|Kupferstichkabinett, Dresden}}
{{coord|51|03|10|N|13|44|13|E|region:DE-SN_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Staatliche Kunstsammlungen Dresden]] [[Category:Printmaking]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1720]] [[Category:1720 establishments in the Holy Roman Empire]] [[Category:1720 establishments in Germany]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox artifact | name = Lewis chessmen | image = [[File:UigChessmen SelectionOfKings.jpg|360px]] | image2 = | image_caption = Lewis chessmen in the [[British Museum]] | material = [[Walrus]] [[ivory]] and whales' teeth | size = | writing = | created = 12th century | discovered_place = [[Uig, Lewis]], Scotland | discovered_coords = | discovered_date = 1831 | discovered_by = | location = {{unbulleted list|[[British Museum]]|[[National Museum of Scotland]]}} | id = }}
The '''Lewis chessmen''' ({{lang-no|Lewisbrikkene}}; {{lang-gd|Fir-Tàilisg}}; {{lang-sco|Lewis chesmen}}) or '''Uig chessmen''', named after the [[Uig, Lewis|bay]] where they were found,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ceuig.co.uk/uig-chessmen/ |title=Uig Chessmen | Comann Eachdraidh Uig |publisher=Ceuig.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-03-24}}</ref> are a group of distinctive [[12th-century]] [[chess]] pieces, along with other game pieces, most of which are carved from [[walrus ivory]]. Discovered in 1831 on [[Isle of Lewis|Lewis]] in the [[Outer Hebrides]], Scotland,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=6665 |title=The enigma of the Lewis chessmen |publisher=Chessbase |date=9 November 2010 |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref> they may constitute some of the few complete, surviving [[medieval]] [[chess set]]s, although it is not clear if a set as originally made can be assembled from the pieces. When found, the hoard contained 93 artifacts: 78 chess pieces, 14 [[Tables (board game)|tablemen]] and one belt buckle. Today, 82 pieces are owned and usually exhibited by the [[British Museum]] in [[London]], and the remaining 11 are at the [[National Museum of Scotland]] in [[Edinburgh]].
== Origin == [[File:Beserker, Lewis Chessmen, British Museum.jpg|thumb|upright|"[[Berserker]]" warder (rook), in the British Museum]] The British Museum claims the chessmen were probably made in [[Trondheim]], [[Norway]], in the 12th century,<ref name="British Museum">{{cite web |url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/news_and_press_releases/statements/the_lewis_chessmen.aspx |title=The Lewis Chessmen |publisher=British Museum |date= |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref> although some scholars have suggested other Nordic countries.<ref>Robinson, p. 14.</ref> During that period, the [[Outer Hebrides]], along with other major groups of [[Scottish islands]], were ruled by Norway.<ref name="British Museum"/>
According to Dr. Alex Woolf, director of the [[University of St Andrews]] Institute for Medieval Studies, there are reasons for believing the pieces came from Trondheim: *A broken queen piece in a similar style was found in an excavation of the archbishop's palace – it appeared the piece was broken as it was being made. *The presence of wealthy people in Trondheim able to pay craftsmen for high-quality chess pieces. *Similar carving in [[Nidaros Cathedral]] in Trondheim. *The excavation in Trondheim of a kite-shaped shield similar to shields on some of the pieces and a king piece of similar design found on [[Hitra (island)|Hitra]] Island, near the mouth of [[Trondheim Fjord]]. Woolf has said that the armour worn by the chess figures includes "perfect" reproductions of armour worn at the time in Norway.<ref name=dlmnyt>{{citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/09/arts/09lewis.html |title=Reopening History of Storied Norse Chessmen |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=14 September 2010 |date=8 September 2010 |last=McClain, Dylan Loeb}} (appeared 9 September 2010 in the newspaper, page C2, ''New York Times'')</ref>
Icelanders Gudmundur Thorarinsson and Einar Einarsson have proposed that the chessmen originated in Iceland, since only in Iceland were the [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]]s called that at that time, while in other countries they used a name unassociated with the church.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.leit.is/lewis/ |title=Are the Isle of Lewis chessmen Icelandic? |accessdate=14 September 2010}}</ref> They further claim that the pieces were carved by an artist known as [[Margret the Adroit]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Brown |first1=Nancy Marie |title=Ivory Vikings: the Mystery of the most Famous Chessmen in the World and the Woman who Made Them |date=2015 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |location=New York |isbn=9781137279378}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=McClain |first1=Dylan Loeb |title=Reopening History of Storied Ivory Chessmen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/09/arts/09lewis.html?_r=0 |accessdate=5 March 2016 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=8 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/books-and-arts/21662487-bones-contention |title=Bones of Contention |date=29 August 2015 |accessdate=5 March 2016 |newspaper=The Economist}}</ref> However, this is disputed by Woolf, who stated that the use of bishops originated in England,<ref name=dlmnyt/> and by Norwegian chess historian and member of the Ken Whyld Association<ref>{{cite web |title=Membership and Members |url=http://www.kwabc.org/index.php/membership-members |accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref> Morten Lilleøren.<ref name="The Lewis Chessmen on a Fantasy Iceland">Lilleøren, Morten, [http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=7695 The Lewis Chessmen on a Fantasy Iceland] (ChessBase News, 2 December 2011)</ref>
Some historians believe that the Lewis chessmen were hidden (or lost) after some mishap occurred during their carriage from Norway to wealthy Norse towns on the east coast of Ireland, such as [[Dublin]]. The large number of pieces and their lack of wear may suggest that they were the stock of a trader or dealer.<ref name="British Museum"/> Along with the chess pieces, there were 14 plain round tablemen for the game of [[Tables (board game)|tables]] and one belt buckle, all made of ivory, making a total of 93 artifacts.<ref>{{harv|Robinson|2004|pp=5, 36, 54–55}}</ref>
== Description == Almost all of the pieces in the collection are carved from walrus ivory, with a few made instead from [[Toothed whales|whale teeth]]. The 78<ref>93 per BM now</ref> pieces consist of eight [[king (chess)|king]]s, eight [[queen (chess)|queen]]s, 16 [[bishop (chess)|bishop]]s, 15 [[knight (chess)|knight]]s, 12 [[rook (chess)|rook]]s and 19 [[pawn (chess)|pawn]]s. The heights of the pawns range from 3.5 to 5.8 cm, while the other pieces are between 7 and 10.2 cm. Although there are 19 pawns (a complete set requires 16), they have the greatest range of sizes of all the pieces, which has suggested that the 78 pieces might belong to at least five sets.<ref>Robinson, p. 30.</ref> All the pieces are sculptures of human figures, with the exception of the pawns, which are smaller, geometric shapes. The knights are mounted on rather diminutive horses and are shown holding spears and shields. The rooks are standing soldiers or warders holding shields and swords; four of the rooks are shown as wild-eyed [[berserker]]s biting their shields with battle fury.<ref>Robinson, pp. 28–29.</ref> Some pieces bore traces of red stain when found, indicating that red and white were used to distinguish the two sides, rather than the black and white used in modern chess.<ref name=dlmnyt/> [[Image:lewis-chessmen08.jpg|thumb|left|The Lewis chessmen in the British Museum]]
Scholars have observed that, to the modern eye, the figural pieces, with their bulging eyes and glum expressions, have a distinct comical character.<ref name="Robinson, pp. 37-41">Robinson, pp. 37–41.</ref><ref>N. Stratford, ''The Lewis chessmen and the enigma of the hoard'' (The British Museum Press, 1997), p. 48.</ref> This is especially true of the single rook with a worried, sideways glance (front right of first image below, next to queen) and the berserkers biting their shields, which have been called "irresistibly comic to a modern audience".<ref>Robinson, p. 37.</ref> It is believed, however, that the comic or sad expressions were not intended or perceived as such by the makers, to whom these images instead displayed strength, ferocity or, in the case of the queens who hold their heads with a hand and seemingly pensive expression, "contemplation, repose and possibly wisdom".<ref name="Robinson, pp. 37-41"/>
== Modern discovery == The chessmen were discovered in early 1831 in a sand bank at the head of [[Camas Uig]] on the west coast of the Isle of Lewis, in the [[Outer Hebrides]] of Scotland. There are various local stories concerning their arrival and modern discovery on Lewis.
Malcolm "Sprot" MacLeod ({{lang-gd|Calum an Sprot}}) from the nearby [[Ardroil|township of Pennydonald]] discovered the trove in a small stone [[cist|kist]] in a dune, exhibited them briefly in his [[barn|byre]] and sold them on to Captain Roderick Ryrie.<ref name=burn/> One reported detail, that it was a cow that actually unearthed the stash, is generally discounted in [[Uig, Lewis|Uig]] as fabrication. After the Isle of Lewis was purchased by Sir [[James Matheson]] in 1844, Malcolm Macleod and his family [[Highland Clearances|were evicted]] and the district was transformed into sheep farms.
== Exhibition and ownership == [[File:Lewis chessmen 23.JPG|thumb|A queen and a warder (rook) in the joint exhibition in [[Edinburgh]], 2010]] They were exhibited by Ryrie at a meeting of the [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland]], on 11 April 1831. The chessmen were soon after split up, with 10 being purchased by [[Charles Kirkpatrick Sharpe]] and the others (67 chessmen and 14 [[tables (board game)|tablemen]]) purchased on behalf of the [[British Museum]] in [[London]].
Kirkpatrick Sharpe later found another bishop to take his collection up to eleven, all of which were later sold to [[Albert Denison, 1st Baron Londesborough|Lord Londesborough]]. In 1888, they were again sold, but this time the purchaser was the [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland]], who donated the pieces to the Royal Scottish Museum in [[Edinburgh]]. The eleven are now on display in the [[National Museum of Scotland]].
Of the pieces given to the British Museum, most can be found in Room 40, with the registration numbers M&ME 1831, 11–1.78–159. Others have been lent to Scottish museums and temporary exhibitions.<ref name="British Museum"/> A range of wooden or plastic replicas are popular items in the Museum shops.
The chessmen were number 5 in the list of British archaeological finds selected by experts at the [[British Museum]] for the 2003 BBC Television documentary ''[[Our Top Ten Treasures]]'', presented by [[Adam Hart-Davis]]. They feature in the 2010 BBC Radio 4 series ''[[A History of the World in 100 Objects]]'' as number 61, in the "Status Symbols" section.
An exhibition entitled "The Lewis Chessmen: Unmasked", which includes chesspieces from both the National Museum of Scotland and British Museum collections, along with other relevant objects, toured Scotland in 2010–2011. The exhibition opened in Edinburgh on 21 May 2010 and proceeded to Aberdeen, [[Shetland]], and the Museum nan Eilean in [[Stornoway]], opening there on 15 April 2011.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-13085170 "Lewis Chessman exhibition opens in Stornoway museum"]. BBC. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref>
An exhibition entitled "The Game of Kings: Medieval Ivory Chessmen from the Isle of Lewis" at [[The Cloisters]] in New York City included 34 of the chess pieces, all on loan from the British Museum. The exhibit ended on 22 April 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/18/arts/design/the-game-of-kings-medieval-ivory-chessmen-from-the-isle-of-lewis-at-the-cloisters.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=cloisters&st=cse |title=Ken Johnson, "Medieval Foes With Whimsey," New York Times, Nov. 18, 2011 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=18 November 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref>
On 3 April 2013, £1.8 million from the European Regional Development Fund was granted to transform [[Lews Castle]], on the Isle of Lewis, into a Museum for the Western Isles. Around £14 million in total is to be spent on restoring and converting the property, which has been shut for almost twenty-five years. When completed the permanent displays will include six of the Lewis Chessmen.<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2013/04/investment-in-museum-03042013 "New funding announced for Lews Castle Museum"]</ref>
== Dispute over location == [[Image:Chess01.jpg|thumb|Lewis chessmen in the [[National Museum of Scotland]]]] In 2007–2008 a dispute arose regarding the most appropriate place to display the pieces. The issue first arose<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/7159656.stm|title=Moves to unite historic chessmen|date=2007-12-24|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> late in 2007 with calls from [[Scottish National Party]] (SNP) politicians in the Western Isles (notably Councillor Annie Macdonald, MSP [[Alasdair Allan]] and MP [[Angus MacNeil]]) for the return of the pieces to the place they were found. [[Linda Fabiani]], the Scottish [[Minister for Europe, External Affairs and Culture]], stated that "it is unacceptable that only 11 Lewis Chessmen rest at the [[National Museum of Scotland]] while the other 67 (as well as the 14 tablemen) remain in the British Museum in London."
[[Richard Oram]], Professor of Medieval and Environmental History at the [[University of Stirling]], agreed, arguing that there was no reason for there to be more than "a sample" of the collection in London. Both points of view have been dismissed by [[Margaret Hodge]], the UK [[Minister of State]] in the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]], writing "It's a lot of nonsense, isn't it?"<ref name=burn>Burnett, Allan (3 February 2008) "Stalemate". Glasgow. ''The Sunday Herald''.</ref> The local historical society in Uig, ''Comann Eachdraidh Uig'', which operates a registered museum near the find site featuring detailed information about the chessmen and Norse occupation in Lewis, has indicated publicly that it has no intention of pursuing any claim to the ownership of the pieces and does not support demands for them to be sent to Edinburgh, but would welcome short-term loans.<ref>Uig News, February 2008</ref>
In October 2009, twenty-four of the pieces from London and six from Edinburgh began a 16-month tour of various locations in Scotland. The tour was partly funded by the [[Scottish Government]], and [[Michael Russell (politician)|Mike Russell]], the [[Minister for Culture and External Affairs]], stated that the Government and the British Museum had "agreed to disagree" on their eventual fate. [[Bonnie Greer]], the museum's deputy chairman, said that she "absolutely" believed the main collection should remain in London.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cornwell |first=Tim |date=2 October 2009 |title=Chessmen 'will never come home' |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/chessmen-will-never-come-home-1-778018 |work=The Scotsman}}</ref>
<gallery> File:UigChessmen SelectionOfPieces.jpg|A selection of some of the other pieces, with a row of bishops at the back and then knights. File:Knight, Lewis Chessmen, British Museum.jpg|Knight on a stout horse (British Museum). File:Lewis chessmen 25.JPG|Back of a BM queen File:Lewis Chessmen.jpg|BM king and queen, with rook and knight behind them </gallery>

page.title: List of LGBT-related films directed by women

revision.comment: /* I */ Wiki-linked subsection in short film's WP pg
revision.text:
This is a '''list of lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender-related [[film]]s that were directed by women'''. [[LGBT]] – and in particular, [[lesbian]] movies – directed by women are an important and distinct subset of that [[Film genre|genre]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=ELKA|first=KERKHOFS,|date=2012|title=Lesbian film directors and their pursuit to successful film careers in a mainstream world|url=https://minerva-access.unimelb.edu.au/handle/11343/37843|language=en}}</ref> Academics have studied the issue of how women as directors contribute to the way lesbian stories have been told.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richardson|first=Matt|date=2011|title=Our Stories Have Never Been Told: Preliminary Thoughts on Black Lesbian Cultural Production as Historiography in The Watermelon Woman|jstor=10.2979/blackcamera.2.2.100|journal=Indiana University Press|volume=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tuer|first=Dot|title=Film Portraits of Women by Women: a Series of Contemporary Films by Women from France|url=https://www.academia.edu/1937844/Film_Portraits_of_Women_by_Women_a_Series_of_Contemporary_Films_by_Women_from_France|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Women Film Directors: An International Bio-critical Dictionary|last=Foster|first=Gwendolyn Audrey|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1995|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> LGBT media—and to some extent the mainstream—have pointed out the difference a "[[female gaze]]" brings to a film.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.afterellen.com/movies/511655-director-april-mullen-mouth-female-gaze|title=Director April Mullen on how "Below Her Mouth" is all about the female gaze - AfterEllen|date=2016-09-12|work=AfterEllen|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lotl.com/Cinema/Below-Her-Mouth-Director-April-Mullen-Speaks-To-LOTL-1682/index.php?|title='Below Her Mouth' Director April Mullen Speaks To LOTL|last=Jowett|first=Katie|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pajiba.com/celebrities_are_better_than_you/lets-talk-about-and-enjoy-the-female-gaze.php|title=Let's Talk About – And Enjoy – The Female Gaze|date=2017-06-09|work=Pajiba|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://screenprism.com/insights/article/is-there-a-female-gaze|title=Is a female gaze possible in cinema? {{!}} ScreenPrism|last=ScreenPrism|website=screenprism.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> [[Television film|Telefilms]] and [[Documentary film|documentaries]] are included in the list.
{{Compact ToC|center=yes|short1|num=yes|seealso=yes|refs=yes}}
==0–9==
* ''[[2 Seconds]]'' (1998, Canada) by [[Manon Briand]]
==A==
* ''[[A Boy Named Sue (film)|A Boy Named Sue]]'' (2001, United States) by Julie Wyman * ''[[A Family Affair (2001 film)|A Family Affair]]'' (2001, United States) by Helen Lesnick * ''[[A Perfect Ending]]'' (2012, United States) by [[Nicole Conn]] * ''[[A Village Affair (film)|A Village Affair]]'' (1995, United Kingdom) by [[Moira Armstrong]] * ''[[Addicted to Fresno]]'' (2015, United States) by [[Jamie Babbit]] * ''[[Alice (2002 film)|Alice]]'' (2002, France/United Kingdom) by Sylvie Ballyot * ''[[All About E]]'' (2015, Australia) by [[Louise Wadley]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Costa|first1=Daniela|title="All About E" puts a lesbian spin on the road movie genre|url=http://www.afterellen.com/movies/436067-e-puts-lesbian-spin-road-movie-genre|website=[[AfterEllen]]|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[All About Love (2010 film)|All About Love]]'' (''De xian chao fan'') (2010, Hong Kong) by [[Ann Hui]] * ''[[All Over Me (film)|All Over Me]]'' (1997, United States) by Alex Sichel * ''[[Almost Adults]]'' (2017, Canada) by Sarah Rotella * ''[[Amazones d'Hier, Lesbiennes d'Aujourd'hui]]'' (''Amazons of Yesterday, Lesbians of Today'') (1981, Canada) by * ''[[The Amina Profile]]'' (2015, Canada) by [[Sophie Deraspe]] * ''[[Amour de Femme]]'' (''A Woman's Love'') (2001, France) by [[Sylvie Verheyde]] * ''[[An Intimate Friendship]]'' (2000, United States) by Angela Evers Hughey<ref>{{cite web|title=An Intimate Friendship|url=https://issuu.com/frameline/docs/25th-sanfrancisco-international-lgbt-film-festival|website=[[issuu]]|publisher=[[San Francisco International Lesbian and Gay Film Festival]]|page=57|date=2001|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[An Unexpected Love]]'' (2003, United States) by [[Lee Rose (director)|Lee Rose]] * ''[[Anatomy of a Love Seen]]'' (2014, United States) by [[Marina Rice Bader]] * ''[[And Then Came Lola]]'' (2009, United States) by Ellen Seidler and Megan Siler<ref>{{cite web|title=And Then Came Lola|url=https://ticketing.frameline.org/festival/film/detail.aspx?id=1703&fid=45|website=[[San Francisco International LGBT Film Festival]]|date=2009|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Anita's Last Cha-Cha]]'' (''Ang huling cha-cha ni Anita'') (2013, Philippines) by Sigrid Andrea Bernardo<ref>{{cite web|title=Anita's Last Cha Cha (Ang Huling Cha Cha ni Anita)|url=http://queerfilmfestival.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/VQFF_2014_Guide.pdf|website=[[Vancouver Queer Film Festival]]|page=27|date=2014|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Anne Trister]]'' (1986, Canada) by [[Léa Pool]] * ''[[Antonia's Line]]'' (1995, Netherlands) by [[Marleen Gorris]] * ''[[Appropriate Behavior]]'' (2014, United Kingdom) by [[Desiree Akhavan]] * ''[[April's Shower]]'' (2003, United States) by Trish Doolan * ''[[Ava's Impossible Things]]'' (2016, United States) by [[Marina Rice Bader]] * ''[[AWOL (2016 film)|AWOL]]'' (2016, United States) by Deb Shoval

* ''[[The Baby Formula]]'' (2008, Canada) by Alison Reid * ''[[Bandaged]]'' (2009, Germany/United States/France) by [[Maria Beatty]] * ''[[Bar Girls]]'' (1994, United States) by Marita Giovanni * ''[[Be Like Others]]'' (2008, Canada/United Kingdom/United States/France) by [[Tanaz Eshaghian]] * ''[[Beach Rats]]'' (2017, United States) by [[Eliza Hittman]] * ''[[Beautiful Thing (film)|Beautiful Thing]]'' (1996, United Kingdom) by [[Hettie MacDonald]] * ''[[Bedrooms and Hallways]]'' (1998, United Kingdom) by [[Rose Troche]] * ''[[Before Stonewall]]'' (1984, United States) by [[Greta Schiller]] * ''[[Below Her Mouth]]'' (2016, Canada) by [[April Mullen]] * ''[[The Berlin Affair]]'' (''Interno Berlinese'') (1985, Italy/West Germany) by [[Liliana Cavani]] * ''[[Bessie (film)|Bessie]]'' (2015, United States) by [[Dee Rees]] * ''[[Better Than Chocolate]]'' (1999, Canada) by [[Anne Wheeler]] * ''[[Beyond Good and Evil (film)|Beyond Good and Evil]]'' (''Al di là del bene e del male'') (1977, Italy) by Liliana Cavani * ''[[Bloomington (film)|Bloomington]]'' (2010, United States) by Fernanda Cardoso * ''[[Blush (2015 film)|Blush]]'' (''Barash'') (2015, Israel) by Michal Vinik * ''[[Born in Flames]]'' (1983, United States) by [[Lizzie Borden (director)|Lizzie Borden]] * ''[[Boys Don't Cry (film)|Boys Don't Cry]]'' (1999, United States) by [[Kimberly Peirce]] * ''[[The Brandon Teena Story]]'' (1998, United States) by Susan Muska and Gréta Olafsdóttir * ''[[Break My Fall (film)|Break My Fall]]'' (2011, United Kingdom) by [[Kanchi Wichmann]] * ''[[Breaking the Girls]]'' (2012, United States) by Jamie Babbit * ''[[Bulbul Can Sing]]'' (2018, India) by [[Rima Das]] * ''[[But I'm a Cheerleader]]'' (1999, United States) by Jamie Babbit * ''[[Butterfly (2004 film)|Butterfly]]'' (''Húdié'') (2004, Hong Kong) by [[Yan Yan Mak]] * ''[[Bye Bye Blondie]]'' (2012, France) by [[Virginie Despentes]]

* ''[[Camp Belvidere]]'' (2014, United States) by Astrid Ovalles and Oriana Oppice<ref>{{cite web|last1=Piccoli|first1=Dana|title="Camp Belvidere" explores a passionate 1950s love affair|url=http://www.afterellen.com/movies/228820-camp-belvidere-explores-a-passionate-1950s-love-affair|website=[[AfterEllen]]|date=October 11, 2014|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Can You Ever Forgive Me? (film)|Can You Ever Forgive Me?]]'' (2018, United States) by [[Marielle Heller]] * ''[[Carmen and Lola]]'' (''Carmen y Lola'') (2018, Spain) by Arantxa Echevarría * ''[[Chaos and Desire]]'' (2002, Canada) by Manon Briand * ''[[Chutney Popcorn]]'' (1999, United States) by [[Nisha Ganatra]] * ''[[Circumstance (2011 film)|Circumstance]]'' (''Šar'ayet'') (2011, France/Iran/United States) by [[Maryam Keshavarz]] * ''[[Claire of the Moon]]'' (1992, United States) by [[Nicole Conn]] * ''[[Clambake (2015 film)|Clambake]]'' (2015, United States) by Andrea Meyerson<ref>{{cite 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202150854/https://clambakethemovie.com/|archivedate=December 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Costaon|first1=Daniela|title="Clambake" pays homage to 30 years of Women's Week in Provincetown|url=http://www.afterellen.com/movies/467413-clambake-pays-homage-30-years-womens-week-provincetown|website=[[AfterEllen]]|date=December 28, 2015|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * ''[[Close-Knit]]'' (''Karera ga honki de amu toki wa'') (2017, Japan) by [[Naoko Ogigami]] * ''[[Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same]]'' (2011, United States) by Madeleine Olnek * ''[[Common Ground (2000 film)|Common Ground]]'' (2000, United States) by [[Donna Deitch]] * ''[[Como Esquecer]]'' (''So Hard to Forget'') (2010, Brazil) by Malu de Martino * ''[[Concussion (2013 film)|Concussion]]'' (2013, United States) by [[Stacie Passon]] * ''[[Cosa Bella]]'' (2006, United States) by Fiona Mackenzie<ref>{{cite web|title=Cosa Bella|url=http://wolfereleasing.com/info/title/6125/|website=[[Wolfe Video|Wolfe Releasing]]|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref> * ''[[Costa Brava (1995 film)|Costa Brava]]'' (1995, Spain) by Marta Balletbò-Coll<ref>{{cite web|title=Costa Brava|url=http://www.bcncatfilmcommission.com/en/films/costa-brava|website=Barcelona Film Commission|publisher=[[Generalitat de Catalunya]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Darren|first1=Alison|title=Lesbian Film Guide|date=2000|publisher=[[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell]]|isbn=0-304-33376-X|page=52|edition=1st}}</ref> * ''[[Cracks (film)|Cracks]]'' (2009, United Kingdom) by [[Jordan Scott]] * ''[[The Cricket and the Ant (2016 film)|The Cricket and the Ant]]'' (''La Cigale et la Fourmi'') (2016, Germany) by Julia Ritschel<ref>{{cite web|title=La Cigale et la Fourmi|url=http://www.filmfestival-muenster.org/2017/filme/la-cigale-et-la-fourmi.html|website=Filmfestival Münster|date=2017|accessdate=11 October 2018|language=German|quote=(The Cricket and the
